prefix_without_chunk: Alright, let's tackle this question about E. coli and partial diploids affecting enzyme production. We need to determine if each of these partial diploid configurations leads to constitutive or inducible synthesis of enzymes when an inducer is introduced. First, I should recall what partial diploids mean. They're organisms that have one copy of a gene from each parent, so they have two alleles instead of one. In this context, it refers to having multiple copies of genes necessary for the lac operon. The presence of mutations could disrupt the operon, but if there are wild-type alleles present, maybe those can compensate, leading to some form of redundancy. The lac operon involves several genes, including the permease and repressor genes. When the operon is active, the repressor protein binds to the operator, preventing transcription. If the repressor isn't bound, RNA polymerase can transcribe the DNA, leading to the expression of genes like permease and rpoS. Now, the scenario says that some mutations are bypassed because of partial diploids. Since wild-type alleles are dominant, any disruption caused by mutations might not completely prevent the operon from working. Instead, the presence of wild-type alleles could either allow the operon to function without induction or still require induction to turn on the operon. In lac operon regulation, the repressor (rpoS) binds to the operator under lactose presence. If the repressor is missing (due to mutation), the operon remains off even without lactose. However, in this case, the partial diploids might provide enough functional alleles to maintain the operon's activity despite mutations. If the operon is induced (lactose present), the repressor should bind, preventing transcription. But if the repressor isn't present (because it's a partial diploid with wild-type alleles), then the operon can remain off unless induced again. Alternatively, if the operon is already on due to mutation, introducing lactose might cause it to stay on longer than usual. So, the status depends on whether the operon is constitutively active (always on) or needs induction (needs lactose). As a consequence, some mutations can be bypassedin terms of their disruption of theoperonby productionof the partial diploids with wild-type alleles at the sitesof mutation. In each case the wild-type allele is dominant to its mutant homologue. A. (a) Constitutive synthesis, (b) Inducible, (c) No production of enzymes

B. (a) Constitutive synthesis, (b) Constitutive synthesis, (c) No production of enzymes

C. (a) No production of enzymes, (b) Inducible, (c) Constitutive synthesis

D. (a) No production of enzymes, (b) Constitutive synthesis, (c) Inducible

E. (a) Constitutive synthesis, (b) No production of enzymes, (c) Inducible

F. (a) Constitutive synthesis, (b) Inducible, (c) Constitutive synthesis

G. (a) No production of enzymes, (b) No production of enzymes, (c) Inducible

H. (a) Inducible, (b) No production of enzymes, (c) Constitutive synthesis

I. (a) Inducible, (b) Constitutive synthesis, (c) No production of enzymes

J. (a) Inducible, (b) Constitutive synthesis, (c) Inducible

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>
